7.39. Let G = ⟨ a, b | a^p = (ab)^3 = b^2 = (a^σba^{2/σ}b)^2 = 1 ⟩, where p is a prime, σ is an integer not divisible by p. The group PSL2(p) is a factor-group of G so that there is a short exact sequence 1 → N → G → PSL2(p) → 1. For each p > 2 there is σ such that N = 1, for example, σ = 4. Let N^{ab} denote the factor-group of N by its commutator subgroup. It is known that for some p there is σ such that N^{ab} is infinite (for example, for p = 41 one can take σ^2 ≡ 2 (mod 41)), whereas for some other p (for example, for p = 43) the group N^{ab} is finite for every σ.
a) Is the set of primes p for which N^{ab} is finite for every σ infinite?
b) Is there an arithmetic condition on σ which ensures that N^{ab} is finite?
J. Mennicke
